qas.question: What did Nesse and Williams learn?

answers.text: diarrhea may function as an evolved expulsion defense mechanism

qas.question: If diarrhea is stopped, would could happen?

answers.text: there might be a delay in recovery.

qas.question: What happened with people with Shigella were treated with anti-diarrheal medication?

answers.text: caused people to stay feverish twice as long as those not so treated.

plausible_answers.text: there might be a delay in recovery

plausible_answers.text: caused people to stay feverish twice as long as those not so treated

qas.question: What happened to people with Lomotil when treated with anti diarrheal medication?
What is contraindicated in support of the argument?

plausible_answers.text: diarrhea may function as an evolved expulsion defense mechanism

qas.question: What did the researchers discover about shigellosis?

context: According to two researchers, Nesse and Williams, <a0_0><b7_0>diarrhea may function as <b3_0>an evolved expulsion defense mechanism<b7_0/><b3_0/><a0_0/>. As a result, if it is stopped, <a1_0><b4_0>there might be a delay in recovery<b4_0/>.<a1_0/> They cite in support of this argument research published in 1973 that found that treating Shigella with the anti-diarrhea drug (Co-phenotrope, Lomotil) <a2_0><b5_0>caused people to stay feverish twice as long as those not so treated<b5_0/>.<a2_0/> The researchers indeed themselves observed that: "<b6_0>Lomotil<b6_0/> may be contraindicated in shigellosis. Diarrhea may represent a defense mechanism".
